articles.headline: U.S. Scrambles to Help Iraq Fight Off Militants as Baghdad Is Threatened
articles.snippet: The White House hurried Thursday to reassure Iraq that it would help its beleaguered army fend off militants who have overrun much of the country and now threaten Baghdad.
articles.abstract: The White House hurried Thursday to reassure Iraq that it would help its beleaguered army fend off militants who have overrun much of the country and now threaten Baghdad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House, confronted by an unexpected crisis on a battlefield it thought it had left behind, scrambled Thursday to reassure Iraq that it would help its beleaguered army fend off militants who have overrun much of the country and now threaten Baghdad.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Drug Merger Discussion Leaves Out a Key Risk
articles.snippet: The merger proxy for Mallinckrodt’s $5.6 billion bid for Questcor Pharmaceuticals does not include reports of incidents involving Acthar, Questcor’s immune-system drug and its biggest product.
articles.abstract: The merger proxy for Mallinckrodt’s $5.6 billion bid for Questcor Pharmaceuticals does not include reports of incidents involving Acthar, Questcor’s immune-system drug and its biggest product.
articles.lead_paragraph: As shareholders of the global pharmaceutical giant Mallinckrodt consider approving its $5.6 billion bid for Questcor Pharmaceuticals, a small but fast-growing California company, they must try to assess the risks associated with the deal.

articles.headline: Brokers Fight Rule to Favor Best Interests of Customers
articles.snippet: The financial industry is fiercely fighting a change in a pension law that would require more finance professionals to act as fiduciaries for their customers.
articles.abstract: The financial industry is fiercely fighting a change in a pension law that would require more finance professionals to act as fiduciaries for their customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: David O’Brien, a certified financial planner, has tried to repair the retirement portfolios of several victims over the years. There was the high school science teacher who didn’t realize she had been sold a variable annuity, where layers of incomprehensible fees devoured nearly 2.5 percent of her retirement savings each year. Then there was the woman fighting cancer, who was also sold a high-cost annuity, but whose underlying investments were tied up in a money-market type fund — one that cost 1.5 percent annually.

articles.headline: Global Rules for Auditors? Don’t Hold Your Breath
articles.snippet: Though a complete conversion to international rules by the United States is highly unlikely, it seems possible that some domestic companies will be allowed to convert to international rules if they wish.
articles.abstract: Though a complete conversion to international rules by the United States is highly unlikely, it seems possible that some domestic companies will be allowed to convert to international rules if they wish.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chris Cox, who as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission tried to bring international accounting rules to the United States, has now done an about-face.

articles.headline: Hostile Takeover Bids for Big Firms Across Industries Make a Comeback
articles.snippet: Hostile and unsolicited deal activity is up sharply this year, according to Thomson Reuters, with nearly $100 billion in hostile activity.
articles.abstract: Hostile and unsolicited deal activity is up sharply this year, according to Thomson Reuters, with nearly $100 billion in hostile activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Endurance Specialty Holdings’ offer for Aspen Insurance Holdings in April did not get much attention from the broader business world.

articles.headline: In Emerging Markets, What Scares Most Investors Entices Oppenheimer
articles.snippet: Justin M. Leverenz’s emerging market fund has outperformed most of his peers since 2010.
articles.abstract: Justin M. Leverenz’s emerging market fund has outperformed most of his peers since 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day has been long for Justin M. Leverenz, who runs America’s largest emerging markets mutual fund at Oppenheimer Funds.

articles.headline: U.S. Bishops Seek to Match Vatican in Shifting Tone
articles.snippet: Fifteen months into the pontificate of Pope Francis, the Roman Catholic bishops of the United States find themselves unsettled in ways large and small.
articles.abstract: Fifteen months into the pontificate of Pope Francis, the Roman Catholic bishops of the United States find themselves unsettled in ways large and small.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — They are rethinking what kinds of houses they live in, and what kinds of cars they drive. They are wondering whether, in anticipation of the 2016 presidential election, they need to rewrite their advice to parishioners to make sure that poverty, and not just abortion, is discussed as a high-priority issue. And they are trying to get better about returning phone calls, reaching out to the disenchanted and the disenfranchised, and showing up at events.

articles.headline: Obama’s Odds With Congress: Bad to Worse
articles.snippet: Representative Eric Cantor and President Obama never got along, but Mr. Cantor’s primary defeat this week may also mean the defeat for what remains of Mr. Obama’s legislative agenda.
articles.abstract: Representative Eric Cantor and President Obama never got along, but Mr. Cantor’s primary defeat this week may also mean the defeat for what remains of Mr. Obama’s legislative agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day in April, President Obama called Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, to wish him a happy Passover. However the call started, it went downhill from there. By day’s end, both sides were arguing about what was said and taking shots at the other for not getting along.

articles.headline: Iraqis Who Fled Mosul Say They Prefer Militants to Government
articles.snippet: As many as 500,000 Iraqis fled Mosul after a militant group swarmed the city, many of them Sunnis who seemed less fearful of the group than their own government.
articles.abstract: As many as 500,000 Iraqis fled Mosul after a militant group swarmed the city, many of them Sunnis who seemed less fearful of the group than their own government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — After Islamic extremists swarmed his city this week, Saad Hussein fled here with his wife and six children. But after one night, he was on his way back home to Mosul, hearing that things were quiet there.

articles.headline: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Issues Call to Arms
articles.snippet: The specter of sectarian war and partition of Iraq grew as Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani told his followers to take up arms against an insurgent army of marauding Sunni militants.
articles.abstract: The specter of sectarian war and partition of Iraq grew as Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani told his followers to take up arms against an insurgent army of marauding Sunni militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The specter of sectarian war and partition of Iraq grew on Friday as the country’s top Shiite cleric implored his followers to take up arms against an insurgent army of marauding Sunni extremist militants who have captured broad stretches of northern territory this week in a sweep toward Baghdad.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Suadad Al-Salhy and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Upset Fueling Tea Party Hope in Senate Race
articles.snippet: Chris McDaniel sees David Brat’s unlikely primary defeat of House Leader Eric Cantor as a springboard to victory over longtime incumbent Thad Cochran.
articles.abstract: Chris McDaniel sees David Brat’s unlikely primary defeat of House Leader Eric Cantor as a springboard to victory over longtime incumbent Thad Cochran.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELLISVILLE, Miss. — Moments after a little-known economics professor in Virginia became a conservative sensation by toppling Eric Cantor, the House Republican leader, Chris McDaniel, the Tea Party’s best hope for a Senate seat this year, got a text message from his best friend in Mississippi’s capital.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: G.M. Recalls Camaros to Replace Faulty Keys
articles.snippet: The action covers half a million 2010 to 2014 Camaros, which can stall if their key fobs are jostled.
articles.abstract: The action covers half a million 2010 to 2014 Camaros, which can stall if their key fobs are jostled.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors is recalling more than half a million Chevrolet Camaros because of the danger that a bump to the keys could suddenly turn off the ignition — a problem similar to the defect that led the automaker to recall millions of small cars this year.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Benjamin Preston
